entries.content: When cold calling, immediately ask for permission to speak or offer an easy opt-out to gain attention and respect.
Cold call opening permission question: 'Would you be completely against giving me 27 seconds for me to tell you why I called? And if after 27 seconds you hate it, just hang up?'
entries.notes: Specific phrasing for permission-based opening with a time limit and opt-out.

entries.content: The goal of the initial cold call opening is just to get permission to have a brief, focused conversation, not to pitch the full solution.
Keep the opening permission request very short and easy to understand, often under 30 seconds.
Approach the cold call with a 'take it or leave it' attitude, demonstrating low pressure and confidence.
Adopt a relaxed and nonchalant tone during the initial part of a cold call.
Immediately pivot after getting permission: 'Awesome. So the only reason for the call today is [briefly state context/problem].'
The initial statement after permission should connect to a potential problem the prospect might face.

Example problem-focused transition after permission: 'The only reason for the call today is many VPs of Sales I've been talking to recently have been challenged with getting their reps to actually use the CRM.'
After stating the potential problem, immediately ask a question to engage the prospect and see if it resonates.
Example question after stating a potential problem: 'Is that anything you guys are experiencing internally?'
The structure for a cold call opener is: Permission -> Context/Problem Statement -> Question.
Deliver the initial permission request and problem statement concisely, aiming for flow and brevity.
Develop an instinct for keeping the conversation short and valuable in the opening.
